etymologies: late 15th century. Originally a variant of traverse, now distinguished in form in the senses below

definitions: A narrow strongly-built stall or pen formed of rails or bars in which an animal (typically a horse) can be confined in order to limit its movement during shoeing, veterinary treatment, etc.; a livestock crush. Compare trave"travail" Now rare (chiefly historical).
A partition separating two stalls in a stable, cowshed, etc. Hence: (chiefly Scottish) the stall itself.
